<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 570, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 847, 729, 864]]<|/det|>
This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student uses a metre ruler to measure the length of six identical table-tennis balls placed between two wooden blocks.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 112, 829, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 248, 391, 267]]<|/det|>
What is the diameter of one ball?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 278, 134, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 278, 166, 295]]<|/det|>
4 cm

<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 278, 336, 295]]<|/det|>
5 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 278, 470, 295]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 278, 495, 295]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 278, 693, 295]]<|/det|>

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 322, 774, 342]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 503, 376, 522]]<|/det|>

<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 533, 824, 552]]<|/det|>
The train is stationary and \(y\) represents the distance from the last station.

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 559, 804, 578]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 585, 732, 604]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 611, 712, 630]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 641, 552, 660]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 452, 88]]<|/det|> A student writes about mass and weight. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 348, 119]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 130, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 547, 147]]<|/det|> A ship which is floating has mass but no weight. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 131, 174]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 621, 174]]<|/det|> Mass is a scientific word that means the same as weight. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 403, 200]]<|/det|> Mass is measured in newtons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 133, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 707, 227]]<|/det|> The mass of an astronaut is the same on the Moon as on the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 96, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 253, 920, 301]]<|/det|> A student carries out an experiment to determine the density of an irregularly shaped solid. The solid is placed on a balance and a reading is taken. The solid is then immersed in a liquid in a measuring cylinder. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 515, 330]]<|/det|> Which values should be used in the calculation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 342, 636, 549]]<|/det|>
value from
measuring cylinder		value from balance
Aincrease in reading after
immersion of the solid		mass
Bincrease in reading after
immersion of the solid		weight
Creading after
immersion of the solid		mass
Dreading after
immersion of the solid		weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A uniform rod rests on a pivot at its centre. The rod is not attached to the pivot. Forces are then applied to the rod in four different ways, as shown. The weight of the rod can be ignored.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 490, 134]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the rod in equilibrium?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 144, 858, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 453, 96, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 453, 897, 472]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a beam balanced on a pivot. Two forces, X and Y, are acting on the beam.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 481, 675, 574]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 670, 606]]<|/det|>
Which calculation gives the moment of the force \(\mathbf{Y}\) about the pivot?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 618, 134, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 618, 245, 637]]<|/det|>
\(Y\times (a + b)\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 616, 303, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 616, 384, 650]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{Y}{(a + b)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 617, 475, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 617, 536, 636]]<|/det|>
\[Y\times b\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[608, 616, 631, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 616, 680, 644]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{Y}{b}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 487, 147]]<|/det|> 900 joules are transferred every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 134, 174]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 510, 174]]<|/det|> 900 amperes are transferred every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 134, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 477, 201]]<|/det|> 900 volts are transferred every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 134, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 480, 227]]<|/det|> 900 ohms are transferred every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 254, 106, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 253, 792, 272]]<|/det|> Why is it easier to push a sharp nail, rather than a blunt nail, into a piece of wood? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 281, 134, 299]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 281, 554, 299]]<|/det|> The sharp nail exerts a larger force on the wood. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 308, 134, 326]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 308, 567, 326]]<|/det|> The sharp nail exerts a smaller force on the wood. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 335, 134, 353]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 335, 584, 353]]<|/det|> The sharp nail exerts a larger pressure on the wood. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 134, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 361, 596, 378]]<|/det|> The sharp nail exerts a smaller pressure on the wood. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 405, 106, 423]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 405, 510, 422]]<|/det|> A sealed bottle of constant volume contains air. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 457, 452]]<|/det|> The air in the bottle is heated by the Sun. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 465, 920, 498]]<|/det|> What is the effect on the average speed of the air particles in the bottle and the average distance between them? average speed of air particlesaverage distance between air particles
